About Us - PearlX Skip to content Multifamily How It Works Residents About Us Media & Blog FAQ Owners Residents Contact Us Careers Multifamily How It Works Residents About Us Media & Blog FAQ Owners Residents Contact Us Careers Electrifying Net Operating Income 
for Multifamily Property Owners Increasing NOIs, decreasing electricity costs, and providing clean energy solutions PearlX was founded in 2019 and works with numerous multifamily owner-operators across California and Texas with more to come. We provide clean, reliable, smart grid power systems to thousands of residents at a reduced rate while increasing the NOI of owner-operators by installing and operating solar and battery storage systems and other electrification amenities on their properties. Our program helps property owners meet their ESG goals with no additional capital expenditures, as we install and maintain the system at no cost. We simplify the process, handling every aspect of installation and maintenance while maximizing the benefits for owners and their residents. In 2023, Antin Infrastructure’s NextGen platform invested in a majority stake in PearlX with plans to invest over $100 million to support growth over the next few years. Who We Are Jim Brown CEO With over 30 years of experience in the energy industry, Jim Brown brings extensive expertise in retail electric services, energy arbitrage, and power markets to his role as CEO of PearlX. Read more Jim has held prominent leadership positions, including Chief Commercial Officer at Just Energy and Vice President of Finance at NextEra Energy Services. He also served on the board of the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT), where he provided strategic insights to support Texas’s energy reliability and market integrity. See less Pete Mendonez, Jr. Co-Founder & COO Pete Mendonez, Jr. is a highly accomplished energy industry professional with a strong leadership track record. As Co-Founder, President, and COO at PearlX, he specializes in multi-family residential virtual power plant development and advanced asset management technology for the Energy Estate. Read more At Viridity Energy, he served as the Director of Energy Storage Product & Analytics, leading data science teams, driving battery storage development, and shaping market strategies. His expertise extends to smart grid solutions, demonstrated as a Principal Consultant at IP Keys Technologies, where he played a pivotal role in developing the National Smart Grid Framework Document and Roadmap. Pete’s dedication to the energy industry is rooted in his background as a Lead Engineer at PSE&G, where he engineered significant solar installations, electric vehicle charging infrastructure, and large-scale outdoor lighting retrofitting projects. Pete holds an Electrical Engineering degree from New Jersey Institute of Technology and boasts 16 years of experience in the energy sector. See less Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet In 2021, Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet joined Antin as a founding member of the NextGen team and currently serves as a board member of NextGen portfolio company PearlX. Read more Prior to this, she held the position of Executive Vice President at Capgemini, specializing in cloud computing and cybersecurity in New York. During her tenure at Capgemini, she oversaw the projects and consulting business in North America and managed the integration of cybersecurity company Leidos Cyber. Her diverse background also includes a successful political career, during which she served as a member of the French parliament and won three election campaigns. In Prime Minister François Fillon’s government, she held multiple state secretary positions, focusing on sustainability and the digital economy, and later became Minister of the Environment, Transportation, and Housing in 2010. Additionally, she served as Communications Director for Nicolas Sarkozy’s 2012 presidential re-election campaign and held positions as Councillor of Paris and former Mayor of Longjumeau. See less Rakesh Shankar Rakesh Shankar joined Antin in 2022 and currently serves as a board member of NextGen portfolio company PearlX. Read more With 22 years of experience, he began his career at Moody’s Analytics, rising to the position of senior economist. In 2009, he transitioned to Morgan Stanley, where he excelled in the Investment Banking Division, specializing in the Global Power and Utilities Group, reaching the role of Managing Director. He holds a BA from Washington College, an MA in Economics from Temple University, and an MBA from Yale School of Management. See less David Bach David Bach is a Managing Director and the Multifamily Product Lead for Hines Midwest.  David has spent over sixteen years at Hines involved in all facets of institutional real estate investment, development, and management across multiple markets. Read more David has deep experience across product types and mixed-use projects, working with a diverse array of capital partners.  David’s portfolio of Class AA development projects represents over 3MM+ square feet and over $1.5BN of capital deployed, and includes over 2,000 multifamily units.  David holds a BA in Economics from Harvard College, and an MBA in Finance and Entrepreneurship from the Kellogg School of Management. See less David Brewster David Brewster co-founded and built EnerNOC, a provider of energy management software and services that enables its customers — businesses, utilities, and power grid operators worldwide — to optimize the use of energy. Read more Mr. Brewster scaled EnerNOC into a public company with more than 1,000 employees before selling it to the Enel Group, a multinational energy company headquartered in Rome, Italy. He has been a member of the board of directors of Vicinity Energy since January 2020 and Cortex Sustainability Intelligence since January 2022. Mr. Brewster served on the board of directors of LineVision from January 2019 to January 2023, Mantis Innovation Group from August 2018 to December 2021, and Desalitech Ltd., a closed circuit reverse osmosis company, from January 2017 to February 2019. He serves as a trustee at Milton Academy, as a global leadership council member at the World Resources Institute, and as a member of the board of advisors at the Upper Amazon Conservancy. Mr. Brewster has a B.A. from Wesleyan University, and Master of Environmental Management degree from Duke University, and an MBA from the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth. See less Michael Huerta Michael Huerta is an energy entrepreneur and the co-founder of PearlX Infrastructure. With a deep background in infrastructure finance and development, he has made notable contributions to the industry. Read more Previously, Huerta pioneered the storage investing platform at Generate Capital. He has extensive experience managing investments and operations for multi-family offices.  Huerta’s career began at Lehman Brothers after graduating from Johns Hopkins University with dual degrees in mathematical engineering and political science. Huerta believes financial innovation and infrastructure deployment serve as the cornerstone for future-proofing society. See less Owners get a monthly lease payment, residents get on-site energy at a discount, and the result is cleaner energy. Everyone benefits. Get paid to install solar, battery backup storage, and other electrification amenities at your multifamily properties while decreasing energy costs for your residents. About — Prime & Pearl 0 Skip to Content Home About Menu Work With Us Private Dining Special Events Reservations Contact Gift Cards Open Menu Close Menu Home About Menu Work With Us Private Dining Special Events Reservations Contact Gift Cards Open Menu Close Menu Home About Menu Work With Us Private Dining Special Events Reservations Contact Gift Cards about us Our focus is on bringing things together—often unexpected things—to make something creative and authentic. We believe a sense of wonder is an integral part of every memorable dining experience in our space. Enjoy a local, hand-selected Porterhouse or Ribeye perfectly dry-aged on-site. Taste fresh raw or roasted oysters from New England and Canada. Choose a unique steak knife that reflects your personality. Quench your thirst for originality with a personalized Prime & Pearl Bourbon or Whiskey. At Prime and Pearl, nothing is ordinary. OUR BEEF At Prime & Pearl, it is paramount that we work with professionals whose top priorities are ensuring the well-being and quality of the cattle, encouraging biodiversity in the landscape and safeguarding natural habitats. In other words, we’re more than a little choosey when it comes to our beef. Our journey to find the ideal herd led us to the open plains of western Nebraska, where the ranchers raise cattle with limited human interaction and all-natural feed. When the health of the animal is of the utmost importance, you get the highest-quality, best-tasting beef. And that pairs perfectly with our aim to serve you the finest cuts you’ve ever enjoyed. Artwork in the header of this page is “Love Story” by Michelle McDowell-Smith. You can view more of her work here. All Posts business coaching life coaching mentoring parables life values biographies books reviews for fun holistica Search Fritz Perls: a short biography, and quotes Ryszard Skarbek Nov 22, 2020 9 min read Updated: Jun 26 Fritz Perls, actually Frederic Salomon Perls (July 8, 1893 - March 14, 1970), a German-born psychiatrist and Gestalt therapist of Jewish origin, is, without a doubt, one of the greatest psychotherapists in history. Raised by an autocratic, strict father and a mother who had very high aspirations for him, he lived torn between two beliefs: " I'm a piece of shit " and " I must be great and great ." This gave him the drive, led him to rebel, and made him understand the suffering of others. We present a short biography of Perls focusing on the events of key importance to his life. Let's examine the new approach to therapy and the Gestalt psychology he developed. Fritz Perls: A Short Biography Despite family pressure to study law, Fritz enrolled in a medical university and studied medicine. The studies were interrupted by World War I . As a soldier in the German army, he fought in the trenches and experienced the horrors of the war firsthand. After the war in 1918 , he returned to his medical studies, graduating two years later. As a medical doctor, he specialized in neuropsychiatry and then became an assistant to Kurt Goldstein , who worked with brain-injured soldiers. Perls gravitated toward psychoanalysis. After graduating from the Medical Academy, he also studied psychology and conducted his psychoanalysis under the tutelage of the famous Wilhelm Reich . In 1930 , he married Laura Posner . Fritz and Laura had two children (Stephen and Renate) and lived a good life in Berlin. Unfortunately, in 1933, soon after Hitler's regime came to power, due to their Jewish origin, the family had to leave Germany, and traveling through Holland, ended up in South Africa . In 1942, he joined the South African army and served as a military psychiatrist and a captain. During this period, Fritz Perls worked on his first book , Ego, Hunger, and Aggression (published in 1942). The next chapter in his life began in 1946 when he and his wife moved to New York, where Fritz worked briefly with Karen Horney and the famous psychotherapist Wilhelm Reich . This was the period when Fritz and his wife, Laura Perls, developed a new form of psychotherapy, and Perls coined the term Gestalt Therapy .  He was also fascinated by the theater and joined The Living Theater in New York. He wrote his second book with the assistance of New York intellectual and author Paul Goodman and Ralph Hefferline , a psychology professor at Columbia University. Goodman drafted the theoretical second part of the book based on Perls' hand-written notes, and Hefferline wrote the first experiential part. The book was entitled Gestalt Therapy and was published in 1951 . Thereafter, Fritz and Laura started the first Gestalt Institute in their Manhattan apartment. However, their activities were not limited to New York City. Fritz began traveling throughout the United States and delivered numerous workshops and training on freshly developed Gestalt psychology. The third chapter of his life started in 1960 and was full of many important events, professionally and privately. Fritz left Laura and moved to Los Angeles . He founded the Esalen Institute in 1964, where he started to offer Gestalt workshops. At Esalen Institute, he collaborated with Ida Rolf , the founder of the Rolfing Method , to examine the relationship between the mind and the body. He also became interested in Zen during this period and traveled to Japan , where he stayed in a Zen monastery. In addition to Zen Buddhism, he also studied Taoism. In 1969, Perls left Esalen and started a Gestalt community on Vancouver Island , Canada . He hosted eight educational films on his Gestalt therapy. He died of heart failure in Chicago on March 14, 1970 , after heart surgery at the Louis A. Weiss Memorial Hospital. Erving Polster, psychologist and Gestalt therapist, founding faculty member of the Gestalt Institute of Cleveland in 1953, said about his master: “From Fritz, I got the realization that a person could have an incredible range in characteristics. I could experience Fritz as the most cutting and as the most tender of all people.” Gestalt therapy, which he created, grew out of Perls's personality. In German, " Gestalt " means whole, figure, shape, and form. Perls took from holism the belief that man was indivisible. On the other hand, the homeostasis concept denotes the organism's ability to maintain equilibrium in changing conditions. Every need disturbs it, and its satisfaction can be called closing the figure. When it fails, we leave the figures open. One of the goals of Gestalt therapy is to close them. One of the most famous Perls' quotes, known not only in the world of psychotherapy, is the so-called Gestalt Prayer: " I do my thing, and you do your thing. I am not in this world to live up to your expectations, And you are not in this world to live up to mine. You are you, and I am I, and, if by chance, we find each other, it's beautiful. If not, it can't be helped. " „Gestalt Therapy Verbatim”, 1969 Perls rejected Freudian theories, theoretical analyses, and interpretations, considering them worthless in therapy. In his opinion, therapy is not about digging up the past, but about experiencing life in the present. Instead of asking the questions: why, where from, what for? He asked: What is happening as it is? The here and now are important. Both looking to the future and the past are far from being in real life. And while Perls no doubt understood the influence of childhood on who we are, he and the existentialists made us fully responsible for our lives. Sartre said, "It is not important what has been done to me, but what I have done myself with what has been done to me." Perls also recognized the full human responsibility for the choices made. Neither the difficult past nor external circumstances can take it off us. One of the key messages he tried to convey was " live up to your expectations ". As a result, the Gestalt Decalogue looks like this: Gestalt Decalogue Live Now - Pay attention to the present rather than the past and the future. Live here - take care of what is present, not what is not. Experience yourself and accept yourself as you are. Stop thinking unnecessarily - instead, look and taste, perceive the environment as it is, and make contact with it. Express yourself - don't manipulate, don't explain, don't justify, don't judge. Surrender to the experience of unpleasantness and pain as you surrender to the experience of pleasure. Don't limit your awareness. Accept no "should" except what is truly yours. Take full responsibility for your actions, feelings, and thoughts. Be open to change and development - be ready to experiment to meet new situations. Be yourself and let others be themselves. In this decalogue, one can find invaluable and universal hints about the great question: HOW TO LIVE? Also, in today's difficult times of the COVID-19 pandemic. Fritz Perls: quotes, famous and less-known Many golden thoughts deserve recognition. I want to present my list of quotes by Fritz Perls . These quotes are wise and full of love for man. They are largely quotes about being yourself and realizing your human potential. Among these quotes, I would like to highlight the one at the top of the list below. However, the last one on this list is, in a sense, a neat presentation of the essence of coaching. A hundred plastic flowers can not make the desert bloom. All emotions are expressed in the muscular system. You can not visualize anger without muscle movement. You can not visualize the joy, which is more or less identical when dancing, without muscle movements. In grief, there are sobs and tears, and in sex, there are also. Anguish is the gap between "now" and "after". Anxiety is always the result of moving away from the now. Anxiety is excitement without breathing. Be who you are and say what you feel, because those who have a problem with it don't matter, and those who matter don't have a problem with it. Be who you are and then you will see who you are and how you are. Allow yourself a moment or two to do what you want to do and discover what you are actually doing. Take a little risk if you can. Feel your own feelings. Speak your own words. Think your own thoughts. Be yourself. Explore. Plan your development by experiencing yourself. Being in the world with its ups and downs, alone or accompanied, is part of the same thing: existing in the here and now. By not living needs and impulses, organismic self-regulation deteriorates, needing to rely on moralistic regulations. Consciousness is subjective. We become aware of ourselves through our body and our emotions. We are aware of the world through the senses. Don't push the river, it flows on its own. Emotions are not discomfort that needs to be relieved. Emotions are the most important driver of our behavior: emotions in the broadest sense of the word - they are expectation, pleasure, and hunger. This emotion, or basic energy, is a life force. Every time you refuse to answer a question, you are helping the other person use their own resources. Fear of death means fear of life. Friend, don't be a perfectionist. Perfectionism is a curse. Guilt feels much nobler than resentment and much more courage is needed to express resentment than guilt. By expressing guilt you hope to pacify your opponent; with resentment, you can awaken their hostility. Happiness is a matter of awareness. Or, is it that you are becoming Freudian by saying: I am unconsciously happy. If one feels persecuted by an ogre and becomes the ogre, the nightmare disappears. If you feel uncomfortable with someone you can be sure there is no real communication. As soon as one is genuinely expressed, all discomfort disappears. ​​If you need encouragement, flattery, and patting on everyone's back, then you are making everyone your judge. Illness, pretending to be sick is a big part of this going crazy, and is nothing more than a search for environmental support. We are sick in bed: someone takes care of us, feeds us, and gives us shelter, we do not have to go out and make a living, it is total regression. But regression is not, as Freud thought, a purely pathological phenomenon. Regression means retreating to a position where one can provide one's own support, and where one feels safe. It is very rare that people can talk and listen. Very few listen without speaking. Learning is nothing more than discovering that something is possible. Teaching means showing someone that something is possible. Loneliness is actually the place where you can connect with the feeling of belonging to the human. Maturity means taking responsibility for your life, and living on your own. Most modern men live in a "verbal trance." They do not see or hear, and the awakening takes a long time. Nothing has meaning without its context. The meaning does not exist. No one can bear the truth if it is told to him. The truth can only be tolerated when you discover it for yourself because then the pride of discovery makes it palatable. Only one phenomenon can occupy the foreground every time. There are two big lies: "I want" and "I try to". There is a lot of potential in people, but knowing how to detect it also requires talent. Things do not exist; every event is a process; the thing is merely a transient form of an eternal process. Everything is in a flow. The body knows everything. We know very little. Intuition is the body's intelligence. The person who is most in control is the one who can give up control. To be present now is to unite our attention and our conscience. Trying is lying. I'll try it means you have no serious intention to do so. If you really think about doing it, say: "I will do it"; and if not, say: "I will not do it". You have to speak clearly to think clearly and act clearly. Waiting for the world to treat you fairly because you are a good person is the same as waiting for a bull not to attack you because you are a vegetarian. You can not achieve happiness. Happiness happens and it is a transitory stage. Fritz Perls, July 8, 1893 - March 14, 1970 Here is the list of the most important books written by F. Perls, with the dates of their publication: Ego, Hunger and Aggression (1942, 1947) - co-written with Laura, Gestalt Therapy: Excitement and Growth in the Human Personality (1951) - the flagship work written together with R. Hefferline and P. Goodman, Gestalt Therapy Verbatim (1969), In and Out of the Garbage Pail (1969), The Gestalt Approach and Eye Witness to Therapy (1973).
